main.name: Matthew Rousseau
main.description: I am a Computer Vision engineer
main.bio: I am a Computer Science engineer who loves working on visually-driven projects. Whether it's building a small face verification app with Keras, or visualising a physics simulation with OpenGL, I always enjoy the challenge and want to deliver a finished product.
main.contactmessage: If you would like to get in touch, please send me a message!

resume.skillmessage: Here is a list of the major programming languages and frameworks I use

education.school: EPITA: School of Engineering and Computer Science
education.description: During my 4 years of studies at EPITA, I was able to develop my skills as a developer and as an engineer. I have become a proficient programmer mostly in Python and C++, with a little bit of OpenGL and web programming as well. Many of my class projects were performed as a group, and I have learned to work as an active role and as leader in such projects. During my final years of the cursus, I have specialized in the "IMAGE" major, whose teachings include image analysis, machine learning and computer graphics.

work.title: Software Engineer
work.description: Development on the company's annotation-training-evaluation pipeline. My first task during this internship was to add features to Odin Vision's annotation tool, where I was able to discuss with medical clinicians an effective annotation process. During the largest part of my internship, I worked on an internal tool whose objective was to run containerized machine learning algorithms on any type of data in a scheduled manner, deployed on the cloud using Kubernetes and Apache Airflow. This tool provides an automation in retraining machine learning and deep learning models, once new annotated data is acquired.

work.title: Software Developer
work.description: I integrated the Data Science department and participated in Kernix's PSDP (Predictive Smart Data Platform) project. The project consisted in creating a smart data platform aiming to improve business intelligence features by providing a recommendation system, and predictive services (dashboard, ranking, scoring, ...).

projects.title: Premonitions
projects.category: Participation in Mini Game Jam 63: Future

paragraphs.paragraph: This was the first time I had ever participated in a Game Jam, in September 2020. Despite the lack of sleep, amount of junk food ingested and eye strain, the jam was a very fun experience.

The project lasted 3 consecutive days, and the team was made up of three programmers, a visual artist and a sound designer. And all of our hard work paid off, our game Premonitions ended up in 2nd place of the overall score, out of 127 games!

We chose to participate in the Mini Jam game jam, as it lasted over a weekend. The event hosted every week invited mostly casual game programmers to participate, which was great for me as I had little experience in game development.

The game jam had two major constraints: the first one is the overall theme the game had to follow: `Future`. The theme is quite vague so we could have our own take on how the future is involved in our game. The second one was picked by the community, and involved using a certain color palette. This mostly penalized our graphic designer (sorry zo√© you did a fantastic job).
The game is entitled Premonitions. The basic plot line is that you are the ruler of a certain kingdom, and every day your court presents itself to you one by one (it's a very organized court).

However, every night, you have dream where you can partially see a member of the court who will try to assassinate you in the morning (hence Premonitions). The goal is to correctly determine who the culprit is, without accusing to many innocent people and cause a revolution of your people.

image.subtext: The culprit who is going to get you!

paragraphs.paragraph: The game was entirely developped using the Unity engine. I had a bit of experience with it, but not too much so I learned a lot. Most of the time spent was searching through the Unity docs, and finding good sound effects on the internet.

One of the features I'm particularly proud of is the character generation. Since we wanted to have a close to infinite number of characters, we couldn't have our graphic designer draw all of them. What we did instead is ask her to draw every part of the characters separately such as the face, hat, clothes,... Once we had all of these we could stich them up randomly and generate as many characters as we wanted! So generally we ended up with fun characters such as flower knights and bearded ladies.
I also added probabilistic weights on certain costumes using the Curve Editor from Unity to have a bit more control on the characters that can appear.

Overall we had a great time working on the game for 2 days straight. As I said before, this was the first time I participated in a Game Jam and produced a full game (may contain improvements to be made). I would love trying again some other time, and the Mini Jam organization is great, the community very kind and helpful. I would highly recommend. :)
The game is available for free on itch.io, so go check it out at the following link:
